snippet: A nonprofit group is shepherding five eco-playgrounds into schools in Queens and Brooklyn to teach children about water and urban infrastructure.
abstract: Nonprofit group the Trust for Public Land is overseeing construction of five eco-playgrounds in schools in Brooklyn and Queens; schools are chosen in part due to their proximity to overtaxed wastewater-treament plants; project is designed to help clean up New York City's waterways and to teach children about water and urban infrastructure. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: The sixth graders at Stephen A. Halsey Junior High School 157 in Queens have a tough assignment before them: design a new playground that will transform a sea of black asphalt at their school into a recreational oasis -- and, while they are at it, help clean up New York City's waterways. So, in addition to benches, play equipment, ball courts and drinking fountains, their wish list includes a butterfly garden and a gravel-lined turf field. Those features will capture precipitation and prevent it from overloading the city's sewer system, which, in the case of their Rego Park neighborhood, spews raw sewage into Flushing Bay when it rains.

headline.main: Getting Lessons on Water By Designing a Playground
